com.bluegosling.concurrent.fluent

Class AbstractFluentFuture<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.bluegosling.concurrent.fluent.AbstractFluentFuture<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of future result
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Awaitable, Cancellable, FluentFuture<T>, com.google.common.util.concurrent.ListenableFuture<T>, Future<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    CombiningFluentFuture, SettableFluentFuture

    public abstract class AbstractFluentFuture<T>
extends Object
implements FluentFuture<T>
    A FluentFuture implementation that is suitable for sub-classing. Setting the value (or cause of failure) is achieved by invoking protected methods (setValue(Object), setFailure(Throwable), and setCancelled()).

    This provides an alternate way to complete the future compared to FluentFutureTask, which requires execution of code that is supplied during construction. This provides flexibility but also makes the notion of interruption vague. Since the future isn't directly associated with a block of code, interruption has no well-defined meaning. As such, this class provides an overridable method, interrupt(), that is invoked when the future is cancelled and allowed to interrupt. To facilitate interruption of a thread that may be executing on behalf of the future, the future is not considered done until after that interrupt method has completed. More subtly, this means that a call to setValue(Object) that "loses the race" with a concurrent cancellation will not actually return until the cancellation completes and any interruption code has executed (same for setFailure(Throwable)).

    The blocking methods in this class (get() and await()) are safe to call from a fork-join pool. When called from within a fork-join pool, these methods use a ForkJoinPool.ManagedBlocker instead of directly blocking.

    See Also:
    FluentFutureTask

    • Method Detail

      • interrupt

        protected void interrupt()
        Invoked when the task is cancelled and allowed to interrupt a running task. This method is invoked when cancel(true) is called and should perform the interruption, if such an operation is supported.

        This default implementation does nothing.

      • cancel

        public boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning)
        Description copied from interface: Cancellable
        Cancels the activity.
        Specified by:

        Specified by:
        cancel in interface Future<T>
        Parameters:
        mayInterruptIfRunning - if true and the activity is executing concurrently, the thread executing the activity may be interrupted
        Returns:
        true if the activity was cancelled; false if it could not be cancelled because the activity has already completed

      • setCancelled

        protected boolean setCancelled()
        Sets the future as cancelled. This is effectively the same as cancel(false). It is defined separately so that cancel(boolean) can be overridden but code can still use this protected method to cancel without going through overridden behavior (or vice versa).
        Returns:
        true if the future was cancelled; false if it could not be cancelled because it was already complete

      • addListener

        public void addListener(FutureListener<? super T> listener,
                        Executor executor)
        Description copied from interface: FluentFuture
        Adds a listener that will be called when the future completes. The listener will be invoked using the specified executor. If the future is already complete when the listener is added, the listener will be immediately invoked. If the listener can be called synchronously (e.g. it will complete very quickly and not block) then consider using a SameThreadExecutor.
        Specified by:
        addListener in interface FluentFuture<T>
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener
        executor - the executor used when calling the listener
